column5: is one of the worst strategists in the series who has categorically failed to reverse Robert’s Rebellion and restore House Targaryen to the Iron Throne (and House Martell to royal favor). I wanted to use this essay to highlight Doran’s plans and where in each he failed to undertake the logical steps necessary to complete those plans. Doran does not merely pretend to be the grass
column6: soft to walk on but hiding the viper - he is the grass
column7: blown by passionate winds yet unable to stir itself to action.Hope you like!The Queen Regent (NFriel)" True link

column2: lovelies!So it’s just under a week before Christmas and 12 days left in 2015. Things are wrapping up at Wars and Politics of Ice and Fire Headquarters (it’s right between the Baxter Building and Fisk Towers) - in fact

column6: it’s Brandon we’re talking about today.   Though Brandon is often remembered for his hot-headedness and typically Stark “wolfsblood”
column7: it is equally important to note just how southron in his training and customs the heir to Winterfell had become by the time he died. His honor was a wolf’s honor – southron in its principle but Northern in its fury – and it was that volatile mix of influences which led Brandon to his death.  On a terribly sentimental note
column8: I’ve adored writing for the blog in the past year
column9: and a huge percentage of the reason I’ve liked it is because of you
column10: the fans. We wouldn’t be a blog-podcast if we didn’t have people reading and commenting and interacting (or we would
column11: but it would be totally lame). You all make it rad
column12: and I’m happy to have found my little spot in this fandom. So thanks for reading my stuff
column14: and stay tuned in 2016!" True link

column1: warsofasoiaf 133860468066 "2015-11-24 13:21:35 GMT" http://warsofasoiaf.tumblr.com/post/133860468066/queen-of-woe-rhaella-targaryen "Hello
column2: lovelies!This is it - my final essay in the Ladies of Fire. It seems weird that the Three Heads of the Dragon series is coming to a close - we’ve been writing it since April
column3: and I feel like I’ve been involved in it forever. All good things and such
column4: I guess. I’ve really enjoyed it
column5: and I’ve especially enjoyed having such great feedback from the fandom about it
column6: so thank you
column7: you guys.And now for something just terribly sad: Queen Rhaella. There is something just so profoundly sorrowful about her life. It’s as though Rhaella somehow incurred the wrath of Fate
column8: and spends essentially her whole life (at least since around 14) being dogged by cruelty. And yet
column9: Rhaella never did anything wrong. There was no great tragic flaw in Rhaella
column10: something heaven was punishing her for. She simply drew the worst possible lot she could (for her circumstances
column11: at least). Every moment that life goes to give her the smallest bit of comfort
column12: it’s snatched away from her. She endures so much in life
column13: mostly without complaint (and for the one time she is recorded to have complained
column14: I think everyone will agree she had more than a right to). She watches the collapse of everything she’s ever relied on - a stable marriage
column17: leaving her young children to the vicissitudes of a fate which had been so cruel to her.Well. What a cheerful bright note to end this on. Read it like comment subscribe
column18: that sort of thing.The Queen Regent (NFriel)" True link

column2: lovelies!In the spoopy-scary spirit of the holiday
column3: I wrote what I suppose can be called a “villain” piece on Viserys Targaryen. Certainly
column4: there’s much about Viserys that makes him villainous: petty
column5: cruel
column6: ignorant
column7: and vicious
column8: Viserys is remembered as a fool and a poor would-be king not merely by readers but by the characters who knew him. He’s not a good person
column9: and his abuse of Daenerys over years of exile cannot be justified or condoned. Nevertheless: there is a way in which we can understand
column11: the nuanced tragedy which was Viserys’ life that does not excuse the monster he became later. By the age of eight he’s lost his father
column16: never to see the only home he’d ever known again. After Willem Darry’s gallant if insufficient regency of a few years
column17: Viserys is alone in Essos with his sister; he’s watched but never aided by the men interested in him
column18: and instead finds himself rejected at every turn for help to regain a crown to which he was only lately taught he was the rightful heir. His end is tragically pathetic; he’s given a moment to think he’s gained everything he ever fought for
column20: and the last thing he sees is Daenerys
column22: making no move to stop her husband giving him his “rightful” crown.The Queen Regent (NFriel)" True link
